timeline.message:
Add Exec support for user and group

Refactor Exec to support command decorators which can wrap a command with another command to execute a shell or change user/group

timeline.bodyText: does it need a new decorator each time?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
your right - this could be a single instance
for the UserDecorate is sets a user/group which I'm not sure you would want to reuse (although we could clear out the fields after calling decorate)
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: For user it would not be threadsafe in that case, right?
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: why do we need this? this will do sudo -E -u <user> -- <command>? Why is -- needed?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: the "--" is to tell sudo to stop parsing args. Otherwise your command could be something like -u root rm -rf /
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: However if user decorator is null then it's not parsed. Can user provide '-u root -rm -rf / ' in command and not setting withUser?
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText:
If you don't set the withUser or withUserGroup on Exec, then the userDecorator is null and it doesn't get applied.
If you have a null user, then it won't decorate the command. It returns the command un-decorated.
In both these cases, no sudo is added. In your example, it would execute the command -u root rm -rf / and fail because -u is not a valid command.
If they are executing it in the shell, the shell decorate would prefix sh -c and it would execute sh -c -u root rm -rf / and fail for the same reason
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: So I guess, if user type in 'sudo -u root rm -rf' it will be translated to 'sh -c sudo rm ...' and failed with 'sudo not found' error?
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText:
You wouldn't get a 'sudo not found' error, unless I misunderstand you.
A user can create a recipe and put sudo -u root rm -rf / as the command. There is nothing stopping them from doing that.
They can add that as a lifecycle step for a component. If a user is set for the component (or if they have configured a default runas user), then it would translate to:
sudo -u <user> -- sh -c sudo -u root rm -rf / which should fail unless the user has a passwordless sudo access
If no user is set, and there is no default, then it would just run as sh -c sudo -u root rm -rf /
If the user running the kernel is root, or if the user running the kernel has sudo priviliges, this would execute and do bad things.
There isn't much we can do to stop that.
If the user actually wants to run the lifecycle step as root, there is a separate RequiresPrivilege flag which they can add to indicate whether the step needs to be executed as root (so they don't need to prefix it themselves with sudo -u root and we avoid the sudo -u <user> -- sudo -u root problem)
replies.author: rbattle

timeline.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: yeah - you'll see it checks if the string is numeric and appends "\#" to the beginning of it - which is what sudo expects for uid/gid

timeline.bodyText: why "arrayContaining"? Won't that mistakenly accept wrong answers if the decorator added some extra garbage?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
It's a poorly named matcher -
From the javadoc:

Creates a matcher for arrays that matches when each item in the examined array is logically equal to the corresponding item in the specified items. For a positive match, the examined array must be of the same length as the number of specified items.
replies.author: rbattle

timeline.bodyText: why is this different from unix in that unix keeps all the arguments as separate entries? Why are they joined on " " on windows?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: from looking at the info about the command,  windows is expecting a single string argument of the command to run, - whereas sudo will execute the command with multiple arguments after the "--"
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: Have you actually tried it yet on windows? Can we get a test which actually verifies the functionality?
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
I have an integration test that runs on linux - I can add one for windows too - is it ok if that is in a followup?
runas on windows is going to require some work to get right - at least on the windows server I've tested on, you have to enter the password of the user you are switching to at least once (and then you can provide the /savecred option to reuse the saved credentials)
It requires the command to be a single string though:
runas /user:foo cmd /k echo hello will fail and print the runas help message
runas /user:foo "cmd /k echo hello" will open a command prompt and output "hello"
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: OK we can deal with windows later. May want to create a backlog ticket
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
Windows doesn't allow user impersonation without credentials - we might need to do something like https://github.com/gfody/PowershellModules/tree/master/RunAs and require customers to store the password for the account they want to runas as a credential associated with the admin account
I'm tempted to actually remove this as it's not going to work unless we have run runas /savecred on the box before hand (and the users password hasn't changed)
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: Even when running as the administrator it requires the password? If so, I think yeah we can't support it
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: I've removed the Windows RunAs implementation for now - it is not going to work the way we need it to without some effort - this needs to be revisited for Windows support
replies.author: rbattle
